title: Marine Navigation Principles & Practices
description: Comprehensive test on navigation fundamentals, compass systems, chart work, tides, and navigational instruments

questions.text: What is the primary purpose of marine navigation?

options.b: Planning and carrying out movement of ships from one place to another

questions.explanation: Navigation is the process of planning and carrying out the movement of all modes of transport from one place to another by sea, air, land or space.

questions.text: What is the definition of Latitude?

options.a: Angle between plane of Prime Meridian and meridian of the place
options.b: Angle perpendicular to earth surface at the place with plane of equator

questions.explanation: Latitude is the angle which the perpendicular to the earth surface at the place makes with the plane of the equator, measured 0 to 90 north or south.

questions.text: What is the standard length of an International Nautical Mile?
questions.explanation: The International Nautical Mile is a standard fixed length of 1852 meters, used for maritime navigation worldwide.

questions.text: What does the unit 'Knot' measure?

options.c: Speed in nautical miles per hour

questions.explanation: A Knot is the unit for measuring speed in navigation, equal to one International Nautical Mile (1852 meters) per hour.

questions.text: Which instrument uses radio waves to determine direction and range of objects?
questions.explanation: Radar (Radio aided Direction and ranging) uses radio waves to obtain the direction and range of objects for navigation.

questions.text: What is the primary use of a Sextant in navigation?

options.b: Determining ship's position by sighting heavenly bodies

questions.explanation: A Sextant is used to determine a ship's position by taking sights of heavenly bodies such as sun, stars, etc.

questions.text: Which instrument measures depth of water below the ship's keel?
questions.explanation: Echo Sounder is an instrument that measures depth of water below the keel of the ship to prevent grounding.

questions.text: What are the two main types of compass used in marine navigation?
questions.explanation: The two main types of navigational compass are Magnetic compass and Gyro compass.

questions.text: What does a Magnetic Compass point towards?
questions.explanation: A Magnetic compass is a magnet freely suspended that settles with one end pointing approximately to true north, affected by earth's magnetism and ship's magnetic properties.

questions.text: What is the key principle behind a Gyro Compass?

options.b: Rapidly spinning wheel (gyroscope) pointing to true north

questions.explanation: A Gyro Compass uses a rapidly spinning wheel or gyroscope, the axis of which is made to point along the meridian towards true north.

questions.text: What is 'Variation' in compass terminology?

options.a: Angle between true meridian and magnetic meridian
options.c: Difference between high and low tide

questions.explanation: Variation is the angle between the true meridian and the magnetic meridian at any place, expressed in degrees and minutes.

questions.text: What is 'Deviation' in compass terminology?

options.a: Angle between magnetic meridian and compass needle direction
options.b: Difference between true north and geographic north

questions.explanation: Deviation is the angle between the magnetic meridian and the direction in which the magnetic needle actually points, caused by ship's magnetic properties.

questions.text: Which chart projection shows rhumb lines as straight lines?
questions.explanation: Mercator Projection has the property that rhumb lines on Earth appear as straight lines on the chart.

questions.text: Which chart projection shows great circles as straight lines?
questions.explanation: Gnomonic Projection is constructed so that any straight line drawn on them represents a great circle.

questions.text: What type of chart is used for harbor approaches and precise navigation?
questions.explanation: Large Scale Charts cover harbors and their approaches (5-7 NM area) and contain all information required for precise navigation.

questions.text: What does DR position represent in navigation?

options.b: Position obtained from true course and speed through water

questions.explanation: Dead Reckoning (DR) position is obtained from the true course steered by the ship and her speed through the water only.

questions.text: What factors are considered in Estimated Position (EP)?

options.b: DR position adjusted for leeway, tidal stream, current and surface drift

questions.explanation: Estimated Position is derived from DR position adjusted for estimated effects of leeway, tidal stream, current and surface drift.

questions.text: What is the definition of 'High Water' in tidal terminology?

options.b: Lowest level reached during tidal oscillation
options.c: Highest level reached during tidal oscillation
options.d: Time between high and low tide

questions.explanation: High Water is the highest level reached during one tidal oscillation, specified by time and height above chart datum.

questions.text: What are 'Spring Tides'?

options.a: Tides with least range during semi-lunation
options.b: Tides of greatest range during semi-lunation

questions.explanation: Spring Tides are semi-diurnal tides of greatest range that occur during periods of semi-lunation (about 14Â½ days).

questions.text: What are 'Neap Tides'?

options.a: Tides with least range during semi-lunation

questions.explanation: Neap Tides are semi-diurnal tides with least range that occur in each period of semi-lunation.

questions.text: What is 'Chart Datum'?

options.c: Low water horizontal plane below which tide seldom falls

questions.explanation: Chart Datum is a low water horizontal plane below which tide seldom falls, used as reference for depth measurements on charts.

questions.text: What is the primary cause of tides?

options.b: Gravitational pull between earth, moon and sun

questions.explanation: Tides are caused by gravitational pull exerted between earth and moon, and to lesser extent by sun.

questions.text: What instrument is used to find ship's speed and distance traveled through water?
questions.explanation: Log is used for finding the speed and distance traveled through water.

questions.text: What is the approximate length of a 'Cable' in navigation?
questions.explanation: A Cable is approximately 200 yards, a convenient measure frequently used at sea for navigational purposes.

questions.text: What does a triple arrow denote on navigation tracks?

options.c: Tidal stream, current, surface drift and drift

questions.explanation: A triple arrow denotes tidal stream, current, surface drift and drift on navigation plotting.
